title: The Labeled Box (Variables Explained)
concept:
Imagine you're moving into a new apartment. You have lots of boxes, but if they're not labeled, you'll never find anything! You need to write on each box:

  • üì¶ 'Kitchen Stuff'
  • üì¶ 'Books'
  • üì¶ 'Clothes'
  • üì¶ 'Electronics'

Now when you need a specific item, you know exactly which box to open.

Variables work exactly like labeled moving boxes!

A variable is a container that stores information, and you give it a name (label) so you can find that information later. Without variables, your program would forget everything immediately‚Äîlike having boxes with no labels!

Real-world analogy:

  • Your phone saves contacts with names (variables): 'Mom', 'Best Friend', 'Pizza Place'
  • Without names, you'd just have a list of random numbers‚Äîimpossible to use!
  • The name 'Mom' points to a phone number, just like a variable name points to a value

In Python, you create a variable by giving it a name and assigning it a value using the equals sign (=).

code_example.code:
# Creating variables - like labeling boxes

# A variable that stores text (a person's name)
name = "Sarah"

# A variable that stores a number (age)
age = 28

# A variable that stores a decimal number (price)
price = 19.99

# A variable that stores a True/False value
is_student = True

# Now let's use these variables
print("Customer Information:")
print(f"Name: {name}")
print(f"Age: {age}")
print(f"Item Price: ${price}")
print(f"Student Discount Eligible: {is_student}")

# You can change what's in a variable (relabel the box)
age = 29  # Happy birthday!
print(f"\nUpdated Age: {age}")

Age: 28

syntax_breakdown:
Let's understand the rules for creating and using variables:

  • Creating a variable: variable_name = value

    name = "Sarah"  # Create a variable called 'name', put "Sarah" in it

    The = sign is like a label maker. It says: "From now on, whenever I say 'name', I mean 'Sarah'."

  • Variable naming rules:

    1. Can contain letters, numbers, and underscores: my_age_2 ‚úÖ
    2. Must start with a letter or underscore, NOT a number: age2 ‚úÖ, 2age ‚ùå
    3. Cannot contain spaces: user_name ‚úÖ, user name ‚ùå
    4. Case-sensitive: Name and name are different variables
    5. Cannot use Python keywords (like print, if, for)

  • Good variable names are descriptive:

    # Bad - what does 'x' mean?
x = 25

# Good - clearly stores someone's age
age = 25

  • Changing a variable's value:

    score = 100   # Start with 100
score = 150   # Change it to 150
# The old value (100) is gone; score now holds 150

    It's like taking items out of a labeled box and putting different items in!

exercise.instructions:
Your Mission: Create a profile card for yourself using variables!

Requirements:

  1. Create variables for:
    • Your first name
    • Your last name
    • Your age
    • Your favorite number
    • Whether you like pizza (True or False)
    • Your city
  2. Use f-strings to display all this information in a nicely formatted profile
  3. Calculate and display your age in months
  4. Change one variable and print the updated value
exercise.starter_code:
# Personal Profile Card

# Create your variables
first_name = "____"  # Your first name
last_name = "____"   # Your last name
age = ____           # Your age (number, no quotes)
favorite_number = ____
likes_pizza = ____   # True or False (no quotes)
city = "____"

# Calculate age in months
age_in_months = age * 12

# Display your profile
print("=" * 40)
print("       PERSONAL PROFILE CARD")
print("=" * 40)
print(f"Name: {first_name} {last_name}")
print(f"Age: {age} years ({age_in_months} months)")
print(f"City: {____}")
print(f"Favorite Number: {____}")
print(f"Likes Pizza: {____}")
print("=" * 40)

# Update one variable
age = ____  # Change your age
print(f"\nUpdated Age: {age}")
exercise.hint:
Hints:

  • Text values need quotes: "Sarah"
  • Numbers DON'T need quotes: 25
  • True and False are special values (no quotes, capital first letter): True or False
  • To use a variable in an f-string: f"Text {variable_name} more text"
  • Make sure all variable names in the print statements match the names you created above!

solution.code:
# Personal Profile Card - SOLUTION

# Create your variables
first_name = "Alex"
last_name = "Johnson"
age = 25
favorite_number = 7
likes_pizza = True
city = "Portland"

# Calculate age in months
age_in_months = age * 12

# Display your profile
print("=" * 40)
print("       PERSONAL PROFILE CARD")
print("=" * 40)
print(f"Name: {first_name} {last_name}")
print(f"Age: {age} years ({age_in_months} months)")
print(f"City: {city}")
print(f"Favorite Number: {favorite_number}")
print(f"Likes Pizza: {likes_pizza}")
print("=" * 40)

# Update one variable
age = 26  # Birthday!
age_in_months = age * 12  # Recalculate
print(f"\nUpdated Age: {age} years ({age_in_months} months)")
solution.explanation:
Understanding the solution:

  1. Creating variables with different types of data:

    • first_name = "Alex" - Text (string) in quotes
    • age = 25 - Number (integer) without quotes
    • likes_pizza = True - Boolean (True/False) without quotes

  2. Using variables in calculations:

    age_in_months = age * 12

    We can use the value stored in age to calculate something new!

  3. Combining variables in f-strings:

    print(f"Name: {first_name} {last_name}")

    We can use multiple variables in one string!

  4. Updating variables:

    age = 26  # Old value (25) is replaced with new value (26)

    When you change a variable, you need to recalculate anything that depends on it!
solution.common_mistakes:
‚ö†Ô∏è Common Sticking Points:

  1. Putting quotes around numbers:

    age = "25"  ‚ùå This is text, not a number!
age = 25    ‚úÖ This is a number you can use in math

  2. Forgetting quotes around text:

    name = Sarah  ‚ùå Python looks for a variable called Sarah
name = "Sarah"  ‚úÖ This creates text

  3. Wrong capitalization for True/False:

    likes_pizza = true   ‚ùå Lowercase doesn't work
likes_pizza = TRUE   ‚ùå All caps doesn't work
likes_pizza = True   ‚úÖ Must have capital T

  4. Using variable names that don't exist:

    # You created: favorite_number = 7
print(f"Number: {fav_num}")  ‚ùå 'fav_num' was never created!
print(f"Number: {favorite_number}")  ‚úÖ Correct name

  5. Not updating related calculations:

    age = 25
age_in_months = age * 12  # 300
age = 26  # Changed age
# age_in_months is still 300! Need to recalculate it!

key_takeaways:
• Variables are like labeled boxes that store information
  • Create a variable with: variable_name = value
  • Variable names should be descriptive: age not x
  • Variable naming rules: start with letter, no spaces, use underscores
  • Text (strings) needs quotes: "Sarah"
  • Numbers don't need quotes: 25
  • True/False are special values (Booleans): True, False
  • You can change a variable's value anytime
  • Good variable names make your code readable and maintainable
